questions.text: In a patient of filaria, Max density of mf in blood is reported between:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: Nocturnal periodicity of W. bancrofti peaks between 11 pm–2 am.

questions.text: Index of operational efficacy of malaria is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: ABER is index of operational efficacy

questions.text: In which of the following Rickettsial diseases no rash is seen:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: Q fever typically does not present with a rash.

questions.text: Considering rabies prophylaxis, lick on mucosa by an animal is which category:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: Mucosal contact with saliva is considered Category III exposure.

questions.text: Rabies immunoglobulin are needed if:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Explanation: RIG is required for Category III exposures and Category II immunocompromised

questions.text: A man presents with 2 skin lesions lighter than normal skin, with loss of sensation and one thickened nerve. Slit smear negative. Treatment is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation: Multibacillary leprosy is treated with 3 drugs for 12 months.

questions.text: Preferred chemoprophylaxis for Leprosy:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Explanation: Single Dose Rifampicin is recommended for contacts of leprosy cases.

questions.text: ASHA gets how much incentive for referring suspected leprosy case before disability:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation: ASHA is incentivized Rs. 250 per case before disability under NLEP.

choices.text: Spread awareness about Beti Bachao Beti Padhao

questions.text: The given image is for:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Explanation: The image promotes leprosy awareness and destigmatization.

questions.text: Preferred regimen for HIV PEP in adults:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Explanation: TLD (Tenofovir, Lamivudine, Dolutegravir) is used in PEP

questions.text: Primarily Polio is infection of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Explanation: Polio virus enters and multiplies in the intestinal tract.

questions.text: India was certified polio free in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation: WHO certified India polio-free in 2014.

questions.text: Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK) covers age group:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: RKSK targets adolescents aged 10-19 years.

questions.text: For which purpose has India launched the "mCessation" initiative?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: mCessation is a mobile-based intervention to quit tobacco.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT part of Kayakalp assessment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: Kayakalp assesses cleanliness, hygiene, and waste management, not performance index.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a history of smoking is followed for 10 years to assess development of lung cancer. What type of study is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cohort

Explanation: In cohort studies, individuals are followed over time to assess incidence of outcomes.

choices.text: Exposed are 4.2 times more likely to develop disease

questions.text: A cohort study finds RR = 4.2. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Exposed are 4.2 times more likely to develop disease

Explanation: RR > 1 indicates a positive association between exposure and disease

questions.text: Promotion of physical activity in schools to prevent obesity falls under:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Primordial prevention

Explanation: Primordial prevention prevents emergence of risk factors.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT one of the Bradford Hill criteria for causation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Confounding

Explanation: Confounding is a threat to validity, not a causality criterion.

questions.text: In chronic diseases like diabetes, what will be the trend if incidence stays same but survival improves?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prevalence increases

Explanation: Better survival leads to more people living with the disease, increasing prevalence.

questions.text: In a left-skewed distribution, which measure is highest?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mode

Explanation: In left-skewed distributions, mode > median > mean.

questions.text: Which test is used to compare the means of two independent groups?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Unpaired t-test

Explanation: Unpaired t-test compares means between two unrelated groups.

choices.text: High risk of Type II error

questions.text: A study shows p = 0.04. What does this mean?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

4% chance results due to chance

Explanation: A p-value of 0.04 indicates statistical significance at the 5% level.

questions.text: Rejecting a true null hypothesis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Type I error

Explanation: Type I error is a false positive—rejecting the null when it's actually true.

questions.text: In a test with 95% specificity, what is the chance of a false positive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

5%

Explanation: Specificity of 95% means 5

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with severe depression loses 5 healthy years due to illness. What does this contribute to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

YLD

Explanation: Years Lived with Disability (YLD) accounts for years spent with disease-related disability.

questions.text: An outbreak has a sudden peak and then decline in cases. What type of epidemic is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Point source

Explanation: Point source epidemics have a sharp rise and fall in the epidemic curve

questions.text: A child eats contaminated food and develops diarrhea in 12 hours. What term defines this interval?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Incubation period

Explanation: Incubation period is the time between exposure and symptom onset.

questions.text: A health worker visits households weekly to check for new TB cases. This is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Active surveillance

Explanation: Active surveillance involves regular outreach and data collection.

questions.text: During a routine inspection of a PHC, vaccines are found stored at-5°C. Which vaccine is most likely to lose potency at this temperature?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hepatitis B vaccine

Explanation: Hepatitis B vaccine is sensitive to freezing temperatures, which can reduce its efficacy.

choices.text: Store it back in the refrigerator

questions.text: A health worker notices that the inner square of a Vaccine Vial Monitor has turned darker than the outer circle. What should be done with the vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Discard the vaccine

Explanation: A VVM indicates vaccine exposure to heat; if the inner square is darker than the outer circle, the vaccine should be discarded.

questions.text: A child develops a high fever and seizures within 24 hours after receiving the DPT vaccine. This is classified as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Vaccine reaction

Explanation: Certain vaccines, like DPT, can cause known reactions such as fever and seizures post-immunization.

questions.text: According to the National Immunization Schedule in India, at what age is the first dose of measles vaccine administered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

9 months

Explanation: The first dose of the measles vaccine is given at 9 completed months as per India's immunization schedule

questions.text: A pregnant woman from a rural area is advised to deliver in a government facility to avail financial assistance under a scheme. This scheme is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY)

Explanation: JSY promotes institutional deliveries by providing financial incentives to pregnant women in rural areas

questions.text: Most reliable anthropometric indicator for assessing Severe Acute malnutrition in infants:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Weight-for-height

Explanation:

• Weight-for-height is considered the most reliable indicator for diagnosing Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM), especially in infants and children under 5. It reflects acute malnutrition by comparing body mass to height.

• MUAC (Mid-Upper Arm Circumference) is also used (especially in field settings), with a cut-off of <11.5 cm indicating SAM, but Weight-for-height is more comprehensive and is the gold standard in clinical assessments.

• Weight-for-age mixes both acute and chronic malnutrition.

• Height-for-age indicates chronic malnutrition (stunting), not acute.

questions.text: Iceberg phenomenon is typically seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Polio

Explanation (Iceberg Phenomenon):

• The iceberg phenomenon refers to diseases where clinical cases represent only a small visible fraction ("tip of the iceberg"), while subclinical, inapparent, or undiagnosed cases lie beneath the surface.

• Polio is a classic example:

o For every 1 paralytic case, there may be 100 or more asymptomatic or mild cases.

o These hidden cases still contribute to transmission.

Other options:

• Rabies: Nearly always symptomatic and fatal once clinical symptoms appear.

• Tetanus: Usually symptomatic with no carrier state.

• Measles: Mostly symptomatic; subclinical cases are uncommon.

questions.text: UNICEF primarily focuses on:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Maternal and child health

Explanation: UNICEF focuses on the health and development of women and children.

questions.text: The headquarters of WHO is located in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Geneva

Explanation: WHO headquarters is in Geneva, Switzerland

questions.text: A nuclear family consists of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Parents and unmarried children

Explanation: A nuclear family includes two parents and their children only

questions.text: Mock drills in disaster management are done to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Assess preparedness

Explanation: Mock drills simulate disaster response to improve system readiness.

questions.text: Most important public health activity post-disaster is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Water supply and sanitation

Explanation: Preventing outbreaks through safe water and hygiene is critical

questions.text: Color code for patients needing immediate care in triage is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Red

Explanation: Red tags indicate life-threatening injuries needing urgent care.

questions.text: Triage in disaster management is used to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prioritize patients based on severity

Explanation: Triage helps in resource allocation based on injury severity.

questions.text: The concept of ergonomics relates to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fit between worker and job

Explanation: Ergonomics aims to optimize human performance and reduce strain.

questions.text: Bagassosis is caused by inhalation of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sugarcane fiber dust

Explanation: Bagassosis is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis from sugarcane residue

questions.text: Needle-stick injuries can be prevented by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Using Hub cutters

Explanation: Hub cutters are needle destroyers prevent reuse and injury.

questions.text: Color code for sharps container is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

White (translucent)

Explanation: Sharps are disposed of in puncture-proof white containers.

questions.text: Yellow bag in biomedical waste management is used for:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Soiled waste

Explanation: Yellow bags are used for infectious waste like dressings and human tissues.

questions.text: A major advantage of deep wells over shallow wells is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Free from bacterial contamination

Explanation: Deep wells are usually safe bacteriologically due to natural filtration through layers of soil.

questions.text: Backwashing is required in which type of sand filter?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rapid sand filter

Explanation: Rapid filters clog quickly and need regular backwashing to restore function

questions.text: The biological layer in a slow sand filter is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Schmutzdecke

Explanation: Schmutzdecke is a biological layer formed on the top sand layer that traps and digests pathogens.

questions.text: Horrocks apparatus is used to estimate:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Required chlorine dose

Explanation: Horrocks apparatus estimates the amount of bleaching powder needed for disinfection.

questions.text: The number of white cups used in Horrocks apparatus is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

6

Explanation: Six cups are used to find the correct dose of bleaching powder by comparing residual chlorine.

questions.text: A common vector breeding in polluted water is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Culex

Explanation: Culex breeds in stagnant, organically polluted water.

questions.text: Secondary attack rate is useful in measuring:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Communicability

Explanation:

• Secondary Attack Rate (SAR) measures the spread of disease among close contacts of a primary case, typically within households or closed groups.

• It is calculated as:

SAR=Number of new cases among contactsNumber of susceptible contacts exposed×100\text{SAR} = \frac{\text{Number of new cases among contacts}}{\text{Number of susceptible contacts exposed}} \times 100SAR=Number of susceptible contacts exposedNumber of new cases among contacts×100 

• SAR is a key indicator of how communicable (transmissible) a disease is in a defined setting.

Other options:

• Fatality is measured by Case Fatality Rate (CFR).

• Virulence refers to severity and is also reflected in CFR.

• Immunogenicity is the ability of an antigen or vaccine to provoke an immune response.

questions.text: Quarantine is done for:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Suspected cases

questions.text: Spot map is used to display:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Place distribution

Explanation: Spot maps are used to show the geographical location of disease case

questions.text: Confounding in a study can be reduced by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Matching

Explanation: Matching balances confounding variables between study groups.

questions.text: HDI includes all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Infant mortality rate

Explanation: HDI does not include IMR; it uses life expectancy, education, and income.

questions.text: Perinatal mortality includes:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Stillbirths and Early neonatal deaths

Explanation: Perinatal mortality includes still births and early neonatal deaths

questions.text: All are live vaccines except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hepatitis B

Explanation: Hepatitis B is a recombinant (killed) vaccine

questions.text: Most common cause of death in measles is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pneumonia

Explanation: Pneumonia is the most frequent fatal complication of measles.

questions.text: Syringes without needles go into:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Red bag

Explanation: Red bag is used for contaminated plastic items like syringe barrels.

questions.text: One ASHA is appointed for every:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1000 population

Explanation: ASHA is chosen for every 1000 population in rural areas.

questions.text: A temporary carrier of infection without signs and symptoms is termed as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Healthy carrier

Explanation: healthy carriers shed pathogens without getting signs and symptoms

questions.text: If sample size increases, what happens to standard error?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Decreases

Explanation: SE = SD/√n; as n increases, SE decreases.

questions.text: A health team conducts a survey to estimate the prevalence of anemia in pregnant women. What type of study is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cross-sectional

Explanation: Prevalence measured at a single point in time.

questions.text: You compare mean cholesterol levels among 4 dietary groups. Which test is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ANOVA

Explanation: ANOVA compares means among more than 2 groups.

choices.text: 98% of patients with disease test positive
It has low false negative rate

questions.text:
A test for Hepatitis B has a specificity of 98%.

What does this mean?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

98% of healthy individuals test negative

Explanation: Specificity = true negatives / (true negatives + false positives)

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of Hill’s criteria for causation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Predictive value

Explanation: Predictive value is not among Hill’s 9 causality criteria.

questions.text:
A new antihypertensive drug is tested in 200 patients randomly assigned to drug or placebo.

Which element makes this an RCT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Random allocation

Explanation: Randomization minimizes bias and confounding.

questions.text:
In a village, most people earn ₹5000/month, but a few wealthy residents earn ₹1,00,000.

Which measure of central tendency is most affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Mean

Explanation: Mean is affected by extreme values (outliers).

questions.text:
A researcher concludes that Drug A is better than Drug B, but in reality, there is no difference.

What type of error is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Type I error

Explanation: Rejecting a true null hypothesis = false positive.

questions.text:
A cohort study on smoking and lung cancer followed 1000 smokers and 1000 non-smokers for 10 years. 150 smokers and 30 non-smokers developed lung cancer.

Calculate the relative risk.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

5

Explanation: RR = [150/1000] / [30/1000] = 0.15/0.03 = 5

questions.text: A study measured the haemoglobin levels of 1000 women in a population. The mean was 12 g/dL with a standard deviation of 1.5 g/dL. Approximately how many women are expected to have haemoglobin between 9 and 15 g/dL?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

95%

Explanation: Mean ± 2SD includes ~95% in normal distribution (12 ± 3 = 9–15 g/dL).

choices.text: The range of haemoglobin in the population
The average of the data points
The spread of data around the mean

questions.text: A researcher measures haemoglobin levels in 100 adults. The mean is 13.5 g/dL and standard deviation is 1.5. What does the standard deviation represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: SD indicates variability or dispersion of data around the mean.

choices.text: Psychological barrier due to resistance to change
Semantic barrier due to technical language

questions.text: A 35-year-old female ASHA worker is conducting a session on exclusive breastfeeding in a village. Despite repeated efforts, the mothers continue giving water to newborns. What is the most likely barrier to effective communication in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: The use of technical language and diagrams may lead to misunderstanding due to semantic barriers.

questions.text: A Primary Health Centre organizes a session for diabetic patients using local language, flip charts, and interactive Q&A. The goal is to enable lifestyle change through understanding. Which of the following best defines this activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: Health education is interactive and aims to change behavior through understanding, unlike propaganda.

questions.text: A district hospital invites experts to discuss the rising cases of dengue. A moderator leads the discussion and there is live interaction between experts but no audience Q&A. What technique is being used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: Panel discussion involves experts interacting among themselves, guided by a moderator

questions.text: A program planner compares the cost of setting up a free cataract surgery camp vs. the monetary value of increased productivity in treated patients. This is an example of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: Cost-benefit analysis compares both costs and benefits in monetary terms.

questions.text: A sugarcane processing worker develops fever, cough, and dyspnea. HRCT shows diffuse ground-glass opacities. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: Bagassosis is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis; corticosteroids help control inflammation

questions.text: Which cancer is most commonly seen among woodworkers exposed to wood dust?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: Wood dust exposure is linked with nasal cavity adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A factory worker covered under ESI meets with an accident causing 40% permanent disability. Which benefit is he eligible for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: Permanent partial disablement is compensated under the disablement benefit.

questions.text: According to the Factories Act, what is the maximum permissible working hours per week for an adult worker?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: The Act permits 48 hours/week and not more than 9 hours/day.

questions.text: Under the Factories Act, the role of a Welfare Officer becomes mandatory in factories employing:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: Welfare officers are compulsory in factories with ≥500 workers

questions.text: A 25-year-old male from a forest area presents with fever, myalgia, and a black necrotic eschar on the thigh. Which vector is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: Scrub typhus is transmitted by Trombiculid mites; eschar is pathognomonic.

questions.text: In a village with stagnant water and high mosquito density, a child develops fever with lymphadenopathy and chyluria. What is the correct vector identification method for the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: For Wuchereria bancrofti, night blood smear is done to detect microfilariae.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by cyclops?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: Dracunculus medinensis is transmitted by ingestion of infected cyclops.

questions.text: In a health awareness campaign, a noisy market and uninterested crowd result in poor message retention. Which is the barrier?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation: ‘Noise’ refers to environmental barriers interfering with effective communication.

questions.text: Which of the following healthcare institutions provides referral services from a PHC level?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: CHC serves as the first referral unit (FRU) above PHC

questions.text: A rural health facility has 6 indoor beds, 1 MO, and covers 30,000 population. It provides immunization and minor surgery. Identify the facility.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: A PHC is staffed with one MO, covers ~30,000 (rural), and has 6 beds.

questions.text: In the three-tier Indian healthcare delivery system, which level is responsible for specialist services and emergency obstetric care in rural areas?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: CHCs provide specialist care and 24x7 CEmONC services

questions.text: Community participation in healthcare ensures:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: Community involvement builds ownership and long-term sustainability.

questions.text: Which of the following is not one of the Alma Ata principles of primary health care?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: Alma Ata emphasizes integrated, horizontal services

questions.text: In cost-benefit analysis, benefits are expressed in terms of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: Cost-benefit analysis monetizes both costs and outcomes for direct comparison.

choices.text: In-depth exploration of attitudes and beliefs

questions.text: A team wants to understand why adolescent girls are avoiding iron tablets. They select 8 girls of the same age and socio-economic status and conduct a guided discussion. Which is the primary advantage of this method over a questionnaire?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: Focus Group Discussion (FGD) allows qualitative insights into beliefs, motivations, and barriers.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a conditionality under the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: JSY promotes safe institutional delivery; sterilization is not a requirement.

questions.text: Which color sticker is applied to a high-risk pregnancy under PMSMA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: Red sticker indicates high-risk pregnancy; green = normal, blue = specialist consult.

questions.text: A child with cleft lip and congenital cataract is referred to DEIC for management. This is under which initiative?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Explanation: Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram covers 4Ds: Defects at birth, Deficiencies, Diseases, Developmental delays.

questions.text: Which of the following services is not covered under Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: Contraceptive services are under family planning, not JSSK.
